Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hikurangi Ocean Bottom Investigation of Tremor and Slow Slip (HOBITSS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Deployment of a network of pressure gauges and seismometers on the Hikurangi portion of the subduction zone off North Island New Zealand is designed to record a slow-slip event (SSE) expected to occur on the plate boundary fault in the 2014-2015 timeframe. SSE occur every ~18 months in this region, so documenting the deformation associated with this type of event and comparing that couple-week activity with ongoing microseismicity should illustrate the evolution of forces and associated hazards in this region. Twenty US seafloor instruments, including 10 from OBSIP, will be combined with a similar number of Japanese instruments for ~12 months. These data will be evaluated together with data from onshore geodetic and seismic stations in this international collaboration. Results will inform planning for possible future seafloor drilling by IODP and subsequent in-situ measurements.

Due to the shallow dip of the subducting plate, the Hikurangi site offers a unique opportunity to document the small signals associated with SSE, for which motion is too minor for human perception. Insights into this newly-recognized mode of plate interaction, are expected to be applicable to other convergent margins. How far 'up-dip' the slip extends, whether all the way to the seafloor near the subduction trench or not, is a key unknown in current estimates of earthquake shaking and tsunami hazard. The extent of slow slip can indicate how much stress on the plate boundary fault is relieved versus building up toward an eventual megathrust earthquake.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Two long standing questions in earthquake science are 1) what determines how large an earthquake becomes and 2) what are the conditions that cause particular earthquakes to produce particularly large (and hence hazardous) tsunamis. The Hikurangi subduction zone of the North Island of New Zealand is an important region to study because there is evidence of large variations in the degree of locking across the fault interface between the subducting Pacific plate and the overlying Australian plate. The southern part of the fault is known to be locked to about 40km depth while the northern part appears to be nearly freely slipping. Understanding why some regions of such megathrust faults are strongly locked and other regions slip more freely is one key to answering the two questions posed above.  Slip behavior on a fault depends on the conditions on the fault interface- likely the temperature, the types of rocks across the fault, topography on the fault interface and sediments and fluids within the fault.  The fault in the region this project studied exhibits slow-slip behavior: an intermediate state between a locked and freely slipping fault. There are multiyear intervals when the fault is locked followed by short (about 10 day) intervals when parts of the fault interface slip slowly such that much of the strain accumulated over the preceding interval is released. These slow-slip events (SSEs) were first detected by GPS observations on land and showed that most of the slip on the fault interface was occurring offshore, but otherwise the land observations poorly constrained the location and amount of slip.  These offshore SSEs could be detected because the coastline lies unusually close to the trench here compared to most subduction zones.

 

Our project was designed to determine the amount and distribution of slip during slow-slip events occurring offshore. The region chosen, near Gisborne NZ produced two unusual shallow "tsunami" earthquakes in 1947. Tsunami earthquakes generate much larger than expected tsunamis (for the earthquake size) and are associated with slip on shallow fault interfaces. The project combined land GPS observations and offshore seafloor pressure observations with observations of seismicity from both land and ocean bottom seismometers. Seafloor pressure gauges were used (for the first time ever) to detect the vertical uplift of the seafloor occurring during slow slip events. We developed a method of using reference pressure stations on the incoming Pacific plate to remove large oceanographic signals due to mesoscale eddies from the pressure records to reveal the slow slip events.  The data revealed a patch with 10 to 20cm of slip on the fault that wrapped around no slip regions that corresponded to the epicenters of the 1947 earthquakes. These earthquakes overlay regions where two seamounts on the Pacific plate were being subducted. The implication was these seamounts acted to lock or partly lock the fault interface in a region where otherwise the fault was prone to slip aseismically.

 

Broader Impacts. Land observations show parts of many subduction zones (including the Alaskan subduction zone) may be slipping aseismically. Our research suggests slow slip events may be common near the trench in many suduction zones, but may be too small to detect using observations on land. Locking near the trench may be patchy in many regions- such that it may still be possible to have large tsunami earthquakes in regions that otherwise appear to be freely slipping. Our observations show the potential for marine observations to resolve locked and unlocked regions of subduction zones and thereby get a better understanding of which parts of subduction zones are likely to produce dangerous earthquakes and tsunamis. Patchiness of fault locking is probably important to determining how large an earthquake will become and thereby determining maximum hazard thus marine data may better inform mitigation planning of earthquake hazard. Better understanding of fault slip behavior near the trench could possibly lead to some ability to predict earthquakes on subduction megathrust faults. The project aided in the training of graduate students and post-doctoral investigators.
